Title.evidence: Swedish Rectal Prolapse Trial: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants with full-thickness rectal prolapse were randomised

Participants.evidence: Participants with full-thickness rectal prolapse were randomised to a perineal or abdominal approach

Intervention.evidence: randomised to a perineal or abdominal approach (randomisation A), or to Delorme’s vs. Altemeier’s (randomisation B) or suture vs. resection rectopexy (randomisation C)

Objective.evidence: This trial aimed to compare outcomes of various surgical methods.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcomes were bowel function and quality of life (QoL) measured by Wexner incontinence score and RAND-36 over 3 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation used concealed envelopes in blocks of four.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 134 patients were randomised: 18 in randomisation A, 80 in B, and 54 in C.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of these, 122 underwent surgery and were analysed per-protocol.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Improvements in Wexner and RAND-36 scores were observed, but no significant differences between groups.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included four Clavien–Dindo grade IIIb complications.
